alert.note: Alert for Brown; Calumet; Door; Florence; Forest; Kewaunee; Langlade; Lincoln; Manitowoc; Marathon; Menominee; Northern Marinette County; Northern Oconto County; Oneida; Outagamie; Portage; Shawano; Southern Marinette County; Southern Oconto County; Vilas; Waupaca; Waushara; Winnebago; Wood (Wisconsin) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS GreenBay (East Central Wisconsin - Green Bay)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued March 05 at 6:23AM CST by NWS GreenBay
info.description: ...ANOTHER ROUND OF WINTRY WEATHER TONIGHT THROUGH MONDAY... A relatively fast moving storm system will sweep into the area tonight, linger though Monday, then pull away to the east Monday night. The storm will bring another round of wintry weather to the area. Precipitation in the form of snow will overspread the area from southwest to northeast during the evening hours. The precipitation will continue through Monday, then end Monday night. Across central and east-central Wisconsin, a band of heavy snow falling at the rate of up to an inch per hour will occur tonight. The heaviest snow will occur in central Wisconsin between 900 pm and 300 am early Monday morning. Precipitation will taper to occasional light snow and freezing drizzle in the wake of the the heavy snow band. The heavy snow band is expected to move through east-central Wisconsin between midnight and 600 am. Slightly warmer temperatures in this area will result in the snow being heavy and wet. It will also result in mainly just drizzle in the wake of the heavy snow band. Although the heavy snow is expected to be exiting the area through the Marinette and Door County areas around daybreak, there may not be sufficient time for highway crews to clear the roads prior to the Monday morning commute. But temperatures at or a little above freezing should result in a fairly rapid improvement in travel conditions once roads are plowed and treated. Snow will not fall as heavily across the north, but periods of snow will continue through the day on Monday. It may also transition to freezing drizzle during lulls in the precipitation. Snowfall totals by late Monday will range from 1 to 3 inches in the Manitowoc area, to 4 to 6 inches across much of central, north-central, and far northeast Wisconsin. Up to another inch of snow is possible Monday night as the storm system pulls away from the region. Be sure to plan on a slower than normal commute to work or school on Monday morning. Monitor later statements and forecasts for updated information on this latest round of wintry weather.
